name: Phosphatidylcholine
summary: Phosphatidylcholine is a major phospholipid component of cell membranes and a source of choline, supporting liver health, cognitive function, and cell membrane integrity.
description: Phosphatidylcholine (PC) is a naturally occurring phospholipid found in high concentrations in soybeans, eggs, sunflower seeds, and other foods. It serves as a key source of choline, an essential nutrient required for acetylcholine synthesis, membrane repair, and lipid metabolism. Supplementation has been studied for supporting liver health (including fatty liver disease and hepatoprotection), enhancing cognitive function, and improving cell membrane stability. While widely available as a dietary supplement, clinical evidence for psychiatric and cognitive indications remains preliminary. PC is often used in functional medicine and integrative approaches for detoxification and metabolic support.

metadata.natural_source: Egg yolk, soybeans, sunflower seeds, liver, peanuts
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

primary_indications: Support for liver health and detoxification
Nutritional support as a choline source
off_label_uses: Adjunctive support in cognitive decline and dementia
Mood support via acetylcholine and methylation pathways
IV use in lipid apheresis or hepatology (investigational)
contraindications: Excessive choline intake may cause hypotension, sweating, or fishy odor
monitoring_required: Choline-related side effects at high doses

items: Supports healthy liver function and detoxification
Provides dietary choline for neurotransmitter synthesis
May assist in maintaining cognitive health
Stabilizes cell membranes and lipid metabolism

sections.text: Phosphatidylcholine contributes to cell membrane structure and fluidity, serving as a critical component of the phospholipid bilayer. It provides choline for acetylcholine synthesis, supporting cholinergic neurotransmission, and contributes to methylation pathways via betaine metabolism. In the liver, PC aids in lipid transport and prevents fat accumulation.

adult.note: Higher doses may be used under medical supervision for liver support.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended; use under clinical supervision only.

sections.text: Liver and metabolic support may occur within weeks. Cognitive benefits may require longer-term supplementation.

serious: Hypotension or excessive cholinergic symptoms with very high intake

other: Excessive intake of choline-containing compounds may cause fishy body odor.
Caution in individuals with soy allergy (soy-derived PC).

items: Signs of excess choline (sweating, odor, hypotension)

sections.pregnancy: Generally regarded as safe from dietary sources; supplement use should be supervised
sections.lactation: Likely safe in dietary amounts; limited data for high-dose supplementation
sections.pediatrics: Not routinely recommended outside clinical contexts
sections.geriatrics: Generally well tolerated; may have added value in cognitive health support

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: Phosphatidylcholine is often marketed under the broader term 'lecithin', though lecithin may contain variable amounts of PC.
IV PC is sometimes used in functional medicine and hepatology, though evidence remains limited.
PC supplementation is being studied for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and metabolic syndrome.
